Pursuing Overall Welfare in Federated Learning
through Sequential Decision Making

Seok-Ju Hahn â€ƒâ€ƒ Gi-Soo Kim â€ƒâ€ƒ Junghye Lee
Abstract

In traditional federated learning, a single global model cannot perform equally well for all clients. Therefore, the need to achieve the client-level fairness in federated system has been emphasized, which can be realized by modifying the static aggregation scheme for updating the global model to an adaptive one, in response to the local signals of the participating clients. Our work reveals that existing fairness-aware aggregation strategies can be unified into an online convex optimization framework, in other words, a central serverâ€™s sequential decision making process. To enhance the decision making capability, we propose simple and intuitive improvements for suboptimal designs within existing methods, presenting AAggFF. Considering practical requirements, we further subdivide our method tailored for the cross-device and the cross-silo settings, respectively. Theoretical analyses guarantee sublinear regret upper bounds for both settings: ğ’ªâ€‹(Tâ€‹logâ¡K)ğ’ªğ‘‡ğ¾\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{T\log{K}}) for the cross-device setting, and ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(K\log{T}) for the cross-silo setting, with Kğ¾K clients and Tğ‘‡T federation rounds. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the federated system equipped with AAggFF achieves better degree of client-level fairness than existing methods in both practical settings. Code is available at https://github.com/vaseline555/AAggFF.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) has been posed as an effective strategy to acquire a global model without centralizing data, therefore with no compromise in privacy (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). It is commonly assumed that the central server coordinates the whole FL procedure by repeatedly aggregating local updates from participating Kğ¾K clients during Tğ‘‡T rounds.

Since each client updates the copy of a global model with its own data, variability across clientsâ€™ data distributions causes many problems (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2020b). The client-level fairness (Chen etÂ al., 2023) is one of the main problems affected by such a statistical heterogeneity (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2020b; Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2019). Although the performance of a global model is high in average, some clients may be more benefited than others, resulting in violation of the client-level fairness. In this situation, there inevitably exists a group of clients who cannot utilize the trained global model due to its poor performance. This is a critical problem in practice since the underperformed groups may lose motivation to participate in the FL system. To remedy this problem, previous works (Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2019, 2020a; Hu etÂ al., 2022; Zhang etÂ al., 2022) proposed to modify the static aggregation scheme into an adaptive aggregation strategy, according to given local signals (e.g., losses or gradients). In detail, the server re-weights local updates by assigning larger mixing coefficients to higher local losses.

When updating the mixing coefficients, however, only a few bits are provided to the server, compared to the update of a model parameter. For example, suppose that there exist Kğ¾K clients in the FL system, each of which has Nğ‘N local samples. When all clients participate in each round, Kâ€‹Nğ¾ğ‘KN samples are used effectively for updating a new global model ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}. On the contrary, only Kğ¾K bits (e.g., local losses: F1â€‹(ğœ½),â€¦,FKâ€‹(ğœ½)subscriptğ¹1ğœ½â€¦subscriptğ¹ğ¾ğœ½F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),...,F_{K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) are provided to the server for an update of mixing coefficients. This is aggravated in cases where Kğ¾K is too large, thus client sampling is inevitably required. In this case, the server is provided with far less than Kğ¾K signals, which hinders faithful update of the mixing coefficients.

For sequentially updating a status in this sample-deficient situation, the Online Convex Optimization (OCO) framework is undoubtedly the best solution. Interestingly, we discovered that most existing adaptive aggregation strategies can be readily unified into the OCO framework. Starting from this unification result, we propose an improved design for a fair FL algorithm in the view of sequential decision making. Since there exist OCO algorithms specialized for the setting where the decision space is a simplex (i.e., same as the domain of the mixing coefficient), these may be adopted to FL setting with some modifications for practical constraints.

In practice, FL is subdivided into two settings: cross-silo setting and cross-device setting (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021). For Kğ¾K clients and Tğ‘‡T training rounds, each setting requires a different dependency on Kğ¾K and Tğ‘‡T. In the cross-silo setting, the number of clients (e.g., institutions) is small and usually less than the number of rounds (i.e., K<Tğ¾ğ‘‡K<T). e.g., K=20ğ¾20K=20 institutions with T=200ğ‘‡200T=200 roundsÂ (Dayan etÂ al., 2021). On the other hand, in the cross-device setting, the number of clients (e.g., mobile devices) is larger than the number of rounds (K>Tğ¾ğ‘‡K>T). e.g., K=1.5Ã—106ğ¾1.5superscript106K=1.5\times 10^{6} with T=3,000ğ‘‡3000T=3,000 roundsÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2018). In designing an FL algorithm, these conditions should be reflected for the sake of practicality.

Contributions

We propose AAggFF, a sequential decision making framework for the central server in FL tailored for inducing client-level fairness in the system. The contributions of our work are summarized as follows.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    We unify existing fairness-aware adaptive aggregation methods into an OCO framework and propose better online decision making designs for pursuing client-level fairness by the central server. (Section 3)

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    We propose AAggFF, which is designed to enhance the client-level fairness, and further specialize our method into two practical settings: AAggFF-S for cross-silo FL and AAggFF-D for cross-device FL. (Section 4)

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    We provide regret analyses on the behavior of two algorithms, AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D, presenting sublinear regrets. (Section 5)

  4. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    We evaluate AAggFF on extensive benchmark datasets for realistic FL scenarios with other baselines. AAggFF not only boosts the worst-performing clients but also maintains overall performance. (Section 6)

2 Related Works

Client-Level Fairness in Federated Learning

The statistical heterogeneity across clients often causes non-uniform performances of a single global model on participating clients, which is also known as the violation of client-level fairness. Fairness-aware FL algorithms aim to eliminate such inequality to achieve uniform performance across all clients. There are mainly two approaches to address the problem (Chen etÂ al., 2023): a single model approach, and a personalization approach. This paper mainly focuses on the former, which is usually realized by modifying the FL objective, such as a minimax fairness objectiveÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019) (which is also solved by multi-objective optimization (Hu etÂ al., 2022) and is also modified to save a communication cost (Deng etÂ al., 2020)), alpha-fairness (Mo & Walrand, 2000) objective (Li etÂ al., 2019), suppressing outliers (i.e., clients having high losses) by tilted objective (Li etÂ al., 2020a), and adopting the concept of proportional fairness to reach Nash equilibrium in performance distributions (Zhang etÂ al., 2022). While the objective can be directly aligned with existing notions of fairness, it is not always a standard for the design of a fair FL algorithm. Notably, most of works share a common underlying principle: assigning more weights to a local update having larger losses.

Definition 2.1.

(Client-Level Fairness; Definition 1 ofÂ (Li etÂ al., 2019), Section 4.2 ofÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2023)) We informally define the notion of client-level fairness in FL as the status where a trained global model yields uniformly good performance across all participating clients. Note that uniformity can be measured by the spread of performances.

Online Decision Making

The OCO framework is designed for making sequential decisions with the best utilities, having solid theoretical backgrounds. It aims to minimize the cumulative mistakes of a decision maker (e.g., central sever), given a response of the environment (e.g., losses from clients) for finite rounds tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]. The cumulative mistakes of the learner are usually denoted as the cumulative regret (see (5)), and the learner can achieve sublinear regret in finite rounds using well-designed OCO algorithms (Shalev-Shwartz etÂ al., 2012; McMahan, 2017; Orabona, 2019). In designing an OCO algorithm, two main frameworks are mainly considered: Online Mirror Descent (OMD) (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth etÂ al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003) and Follow-The-Regularized-Leader (FTRL) (Abernethy etÂ al., 2009; Hazan & Kale, 2010; Agarwal & Hazan, 2005; Shalev-Shwartz & Singer, 2006). One of popular instantiations of both frameworks is the Online Portfolio Selection (OPS) algorithm, of which decision space is restricted to a probability simplex. The universal portfolio algorithm is the first that yields an optimal theoretical regret, ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(K\log{T})) despite its heavy computation (ğ’ªâ€‹(K4â€‹T14)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾4superscriptğ‘‡14\mathcal{O}(K^{4}T^{14})) (Cover, 1991), the Online Gradient Descent (Zinkevich, 2003) and the Exponentiated Gradient (EG) (Helmbold etÂ al., 1998) show slightly worse regrets (both are ğ’ªâ€‹(T)ğ’ªğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{T})), but can be executed in linear runtime in practice (ğ’ªâ€‹(K)ğ’ªğ¾\mathcal{O}(K)). Plus, the Online Newton Step (ONS) (Agarwal etÂ al., 2006; Hazan etÂ al., 2007) presents logarithmic regret with quadratic runtime in Kğ¾K. Since these OPS algorithms are proven to perform well when the decision is a probability vector, we adopt them for finding adaptive mixing coefficients to achieve performance fairness in FL. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to consider fair FL algorithms under the OCO framework.

3.2 Online Convex Optimization as a Unified Language

To mitigate the performance inequalities across clients, adaptive mixing coefficients can be estimated in response to local signals (e.g., local losses of a global model). Intriguingly, the adaptive aggregation strategies in existing fair FL methods (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2019, 2020a; Zhang etÂ al., 2022) can be readily unified into one framework, borrowing the language of OCO.

This is widely known as EGÂ (Helmbold etÂ al., 1998), a special realization of OMDÂ (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth etÂ al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003). To sum up, we can interpret the aggregation mechanism in FL is secretly a result of the serverâ€™s sequential decision making behind the scene. Since the sequential learning scheme is well-behaved in a sample-deficient setting, adopting OCO is surely a suitable tactic for the server in that only a few bits are provided to update the mixing coefficients in each FL round, e.g, the number of local responses collected from the clients is at most Kğ¾K. However, existing methods have not been devised with sequential decision making in mind. Therefore, one can easily find suboptimal designs inherent in existing methods from an OCO perspective.

3.3 Sequential Probability Assignment

To address the client-level fairness, the server should make an adaptive mixing coefficient vector, ğ’‘(t)âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\in\Delta_{K-1}, for each round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]. In other words, the server needs to assign appropriate probabilities sequentially to local updates in every FL communication round.

Notably, this fairly resembles OPS, which seeks to maximize an investorâ€™s cumulative profits on a set of Kğ¾K assets during Tğ‘‡T periods, by assigning his/her wealth ğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1ğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1} to each asset every time. In the OPS, the investor observes a price of all assets, ğ’“(t)âˆˆâ„Ksuperscriptğ’“ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ¾\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} for each time tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T] and accumulates corresponding wealth according to the portfolio ğ’‘(t)âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\in\Delta_{K-1}. After Tğ‘‡T periods, achieved cumulative profits is represented as âˆt=1T(1+âŸ¨ğ’‘(t),ğ’“(t)âŸ©)superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘¡1ğ‘‡1superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡\prod_{t=1}^{T}\left(1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right), or in the form of logarithmic growth ratio, âˆ‘t=1Tlogâ¡(1+âŸ¨ğ’‘(t),ğ’“(t)âŸ©)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡1superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\log\left(1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right). In other words, one can view that OPS algorithms adopt negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss.

Again, the OPS algorithm can serve as a metaphor for the central serverâ€™s fairness-aware online decision making in FL. For example, one can regard a response (i.e., local losses) of Kğ¾K clients at a specific round tğ‘¡t the same as returns of assets on the day tğ‘¡t. Similarly, by considering cumulative losses (i.e., cumulative wealth) achieved until tğ‘¡t, the server can determine the next mixing coefficients (i.e., portfolio ratios) in Î”Kâˆ’1subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\Delta_{K-1}. In the same context, the negative logarithmic growth can also be adopted as the decision loss. Accordingly, we can adopt well-established OPS strategies for achieving client-level fairness in FL.

Regret(T)â€‹(ğ’‘â‹†)=âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘(t))âˆ’âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘â‹†)superscriptRegretğ‘‡superscriptğ’‘â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘â‹†\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star})=\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)})-\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\end{gathered} (5)

In finite time Tğ‘‡T, an online decision making strategy should guarantee that the regret grows sublinearly. Therefore, when OPS strategies are modified for the fair FL, we should check if the strategy can guarantee vanishing regret upper bound in Tğ‘‡T. Besides, we should also consider the dependency on Kğ¾K due to practical constraints of the federated system.

4 Proposed Methods

4.1 Improved Design for Better Decision Making

From the RemarkÂ 3.1 and TableÂ 1, one can easily notice suboptimal designs of existing methods in terms of OCO, as follows.

  1. a)

    Existing methods are stateless in making a new decision, pi(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘–p^{(t+1)}_{i}. The previous decision is ignored as a fixed value (pi(t)=ni/nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›p^{(t)}_{i}=n_{i}/n) in the subsequent decision making. This naive reliance on static coefficients still runs the risk of violating client-level fairness.

  2. b)

    The decision maker sticks to a fixed and arbitrary step size Î·ğœ‚\eta, or a fixed regularizer Râ€‹(ğ’‘)ğ‘…ğ’‘R(\boldsymbol{p}) across tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], which can significantly affect the performance of OCO algorithms and should be manually selected.

  3. c)

    The decision loss is neither Lipschitz continuous nor strictly convex, which is related to achieving a sublinear regret.

As a remedy for handling a and b, the OMD objective for the server (i.e., (2)) can be replaced as follows.

ğ’‘(t+1)=argâ€‹minğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1tâ„“(Ï„)â€‹(ğ’‘)+R(t+1)â€‹(ğ’‘)superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptargminğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptâ„“ğœğ’‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1ğ’‘\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}\ell^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) (6)

This is also known as FTRL objective (Abernethy etÂ al., 2009; Hazan & Kale, 2010; Agarwal & Hazan, 2005; Shalev-Shwartz & Singer, 2006), which is inherently a stateful sequential decision making algorithm that adapts to histories of decision losses, âˆ‘Ï„=1tâ„“(Ï„)â€‹(ğ’‘)superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptâ„“ğœğ’‘\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\ell^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right), where â„“(t):Î”Kâˆ’1Ã—â„Kâ†’â„:superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡â†’subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptâ„ğ¾â„\ell^{(t)}:\Delta_{K-1}\times\mathbb{R}^{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, with the time-varying regularizer R(t):Î”Kâˆ’1â†’â„:superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡â†’subscriptÎ”ğ¾1â„R^{(t)}:\Delta_{K-1}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. Note that the time-varying regularizer is sometimes represented as, Î·(t+1)â€‹Râ€‹(ğ’‘)superscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1ğ‘…ğ’‘\eta^{(t+1)}R(\boldsymbol{p}), a fixed regularizer Râ€‹(ğ’‘)ğ‘…ğ’‘R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) multiplied by a time-varying step size, Î·(t+1)âˆˆâ„â‰¥0superscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1subscriptâ„absent0\eta^{(t+1)}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, which can later be automatically determined from the regret analysis (see e.g., RemarkÂ 4.5).

Additionally, when equipped with the negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss (i.e., (4)), the problem c can be addressed due to its strict convexity and Lipscthiz continuity. (See Lemma 4.1) Note that when the loss function is convex, we can run the FTRL with a linearized loss (i.e., â„“~(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)=âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’ˆ(t)âŸ©superscript~â„“ğ‘¡ğ’‘ğ’‘superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\rangle where ğ’ˆ(t)=âˆ‡â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘(t))superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡âˆ‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)). This is useful in that a closed-form update can be obtained thanks to the properties of the Fenchel conjugate (see Remark 4.5).

4.2 AAggFF: Adaptive Aggregation for Fair Federated Learning

Based on the improved objective design derived from the FTRL, we now introduce our methods, AAggFF, an acronym of Adaptive Aggregation for Fair Federated Learning). Mirroring the practical requirements of FL, we further subdivide into two algorithms: AAggFF-S for the cross-silo setting and AAggFF-D for the cross-device setting.

4.2.1 AAggFF-S: Algorithm for the Cross-Silo Federated Learning

In the cross-silo setting, it is typically assumed that all Kğ¾K clients participate in Tğ‘‡T rounds, since there are a moderately small number of clients in the FL system. Therefore, the serverâ€™s stateful decision making is beneficial for enhancing overall welfare across federation rounds. This is also favorable since existing OPS algorithms can be readily adopted.

Online Newton Step (Agarwal etÂ al., 2006; Hazan etÂ al., 2007)

The ONS algorithm updates a new decision as follows (Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are constants to be determined).

ğ’‘(t+1)=argâ€‹minğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1tâ„“~(Ï„)â€‹(ğ’‘)+Î±2â€‹â€–ğ’‘â€–22+Î²2â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1t(âŸ¨ğ’ˆ(Ï„),ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’‘(Ï„)âŸ©)2superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptargminğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscript~â„“ğœğ’‘ğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’‘22ğ›½2superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptsuperscriptğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ’‘ğœ2\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}\\ +\frac{\beta}{2}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}(\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\rangle)^{2}\end{gathered} (7)

The ONS can be reduced to the FTRL objective introduced in (6). We choose ONS in that its regret is optimal in Tğ‘‡T, which is also a dominating constant for the cross-silo FL setting: ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(L_{\infty}K\log{T}) regret upper bound, where Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty} is the Lipschitz constant of decision loss w.r.t. âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥âˆ\|\cdot\|_{\infty}. That is, Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty} should be finite for a vanishing regret (see TheoremÂ 5.1).

Necessity of Bounded Response

Note that the Lipchitz continuity of the negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss is determined as follows.

Lemma 4.1.

From now on, all proofs are deferred to AppendixÂ A.2. According to the LemmaÂ 4.1, the Lipschitz constant of the decision loss, Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty}, is dependent upon the range of a response vectorâ€™s element. While from the unification result in TableÂ 1, one can easily notice that the response is constructed from local losses collected in round tğ‘¡t, Fiâ€‹(ğœ½(t))âˆˆâ„â‰¥0,iâˆˆ[K]formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡subscriptâ„absent0ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ¾F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0},i\in[K].

This is a scalar value calculated from a local training set of each client, using the current model ğœ½(t)superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} before its local update. Since the local loss function is typically unbounded above (e.g., cross-entropy), it should be transformed into bounded values to satisfy the Lipschitz continuity. In existing fair FL methods, however, all responses are not bounded above, thus we cannot guarantee the Lipschitz continuity.

To ensure a bounded response, we propose to use a transformation denoted as Ï(t)â€‹(â‹…)superscriptğœŒğ‘¡â‹…\rho^{(t)}(\cdot), inspired by the cumulative distribution function (CDF) as follows.

Definition 4.2.

Note again that the larger mixing coefficient should be assigned for the larger local loss. In such a perspective, using the CDF for transforming a loss value is an acceptable approach in that the CDF value is a good indicator for estimating â€œhow large a specific local loss isâ€, relative to local losses from other clients. To instill the comparative nature, local losses are divided by the average of observed losses in time tğ‘¡t before applying the transformation. As a result, all local losses are centered on 1 in expectation. See AppendixÂ B.1 for detailed discussions.

In summary, the whole procedure of AAggFF-S is illustrated as a pseudocode in AlgorithmÂ 2.

4.2.2 AAggFF-D: Algorithm for the Cross-Device Federated Learning

Unlike the cross-silo setting, we cannot be naÃ¯vely edopt existing OCO algorithms for finding adaptive mixing coefficients in the cross-device setting. It is attributed to the large number of participating clients in this special setting. Since the number of participating clients (Kğ¾K) is massive (e.g., Android users are over 3 billion (Curry, 2023)), the dependence on Kğ¾K in terms of regret bound and algorithm runtime is as significant as a total communication round Tğ‘‡T.

Linear Runtime OCO Algorithm

The ONS has regret proportional to Kğ¾K and runs in ğ’ªâ€‹(K2+K3)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾2superscriptğ¾3\mathcal{O}\left(K^{2}+K^{3}\right)111A generalized projection required for the Online Newton Step that can be solved in ğ’ª~â€‹(K3)~ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¾3\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(K^{3}\right) (Agarwal etÂ al., 2006; Hazan etÂ al., 2007). per round, which is nearly impossible to be adopted for the cross-device FL setting due to large Kğ¾K, even though the logarithmic regret is guaranteed in Tğ‘‡T. Instead, we can exploit the variant of EG adapted to FTRL (Orabona, 2019), which can be run in ğ’ªâ€‹(K)ğ’ªğ¾\mathcal{O}\left(K\right) time per round.

Still, the regret bound gets worse than that of ONS, as ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Tâ€‹logâ¡K)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‡ğ¾\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right) (see Theorem 5.2).

Partially Observed Response

The large number of clients coerces the FL system to introduce the client sampling scheme in each round. Therefore, the decision maker (i.e., the central server) cannot always observe all entries of a response vector per round. This is problematic in terms of OCO, since OCO algorithms assume that they can acquire intact response vector for every round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]. Instead, when the client sampling is introduced, the learner can only observe entries of sampled client indices in the round tğ‘¡t, denoted as S(t)superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S^{(t)}.

To make a new decision using a partially observed response vector, the effect of unobserved entries should be appropriately estimated. We solve this problem by adopting a doubly robust (DR) estimator (Robins etÂ al., 1994; Bang & Robins, 2005) for the expectation of the response vector. The rationale behind the adoption of the DR estimator is the fact that the unobserved entries are missing data.

For handling the missingness problem, the DR estimator combines inverse probability weighting (IPW (Auer etÂ al., 2002)) estimator and imputation mechanism, where the former is to adjust the weight of observed entries by the inverse of its observation probability (i.e., client sampling probability), and the latter is to fill unobserved entries with appropriate values specific to a given task.

Similar to the IPW estimator, the DR estimator is an unbiased estimator when the true observation probability is known. Since we sample clients uniformly at random without replacement, the observation probability is known (i.e., Câˆˆ(0,1)ğ¶01C\in(0,1)) to the algorithm.

Lemma 4.3.

Denote C=Pâ€‹(iâˆˆS(t))ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘–superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡C=P\left(i\in S^{(t)}\right) as a client sampling probability of a cross-device FL system for every round tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]. The DR estimator ğ«Ë˜(t)superscriptË˜ğ«ğ‘¡\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)}, of which element is defined in (10) is an unbiased estimator of given partially observed response vector ğ«(t)superscriptğ«ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}. i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[ğ«Ë˜(t)]=ğ«(t)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptË˜ğ«ğ‘¡superscriptğ«ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)}\right]=\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}.

where rÂ¯(t)=1|S(t)|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆS(t)ri(t)superscriptÂ¯rğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡\bar{\mathrm{r}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{\left|S^{(t)}\right|}\sum_{i\in S^{(t)}}r_{i}^{(t)}.

Still, it is required to guarantee that the gradient vector from the DR estimator is also an unbiased estimator of a true gradient of a decision loss. Unfortunately, the gradient of a decision loss is not linear in the response vector due to its fractional form: ğ’ˆ(t)=âˆ‡â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘(t))=âˆ’ğ’“(t)1+âŸ¨ğ’‘(t),ğ’“(t)âŸ©superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡âˆ‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle}.

To sum up, we can update a new decision using this unbiased and linearly approximated gradient estimator even if only a partially observed response vector is provided (i.e., mixing coefficients of unsampled clients can also be updated). 5 Regret Analysis

In this section, we provide theoretical guarantees of our methods, AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D in terms of sequential decision making. The common objective for OCO algorithms is to minimize the regret across a sequence of decision losses in eq.Â (5). We provide sublinear regret upper bounds in terms of Tğ‘‡T as follows.

Theorem 5.1.

(Regret Upper Bound for AAggFF-S (i.e., ONS (Agarwal etÂ al., 2006; Hazan etÂ al., 2007))) With the notation in eq.Â (7), suppose for every ğ©âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1ğ©subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, and for every tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], let the decisions {ğ©(t):tâˆˆ[T]}conditional-setsuperscriptğ©ğ‘¡ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡\{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}:t\in[T]\} be derived by AAggFF-S for Kğ¾K clients during Tğ‘‡T rounds in AlgorithmÂ 2. Then, the regret defined in eq.Â (5) is bounded above as follows, where Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are determined as Î±=4â€‹Kâ€‹Lâˆ,Î²=14â€‹Lâˆformulae-sequenceğ›¼4ğ¾subscriptğ¿ğ›½14subscriptğ¿\alpha=4KL_{\infty},\beta=\frac{1}{4L_{\infty}}.

From the TheoremÂ 5.1, we can enjoy ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Kâ€‹logâ¡T)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\log{T}\right) regret upper bound, which is an acceptable result, considering a typical assumption in the cross-silo setting (i.e., K<Tğ¾ğ‘‡K<T).

For the cross-device setting, we first present the full synchronization setting, which requires no extra adjustment.

(Regret Upper Bound for AAggFF-D with Full-Client Participation) With the notation in (9), suppose for every ğ©âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1ğ©subscriptÎ”ğ¾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, and for every tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], let the decisions {ğ©(t):tâˆˆ[T]}conditional-setsuperscriptğ©ğ‘¡ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡\{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}:t\in[T]\} be derived by AAggFF-D for Kğ¾K clients with client sampling probability C=1ğ¶1C=1 during Tğ‘‡T rounds in AlgorithmÂ 3. When equipped with a client sampling, the randomness from the sampling should be considered. Due to local losses of selected clients can only be observed, AAggFF-D should be equipped with the unbiased estimator of a response vector (from LemmaÂ 4.3) and a corresponding linearly approximated gradient vector (from LemmaÂ 4.4). Since they are unbiased estimators, the expected regret is also the same.

6 Experimental Results

We design experiments to evaluate empirical performances of our proposed framework AAggFF, composed of sub-methods AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D.

Experimental Setup

We conduct experiments on datasets mirroring realistic scenarios in FL systems: multiple modalities (vision, text, speech, and tabular form) and natural data partitioning. We briefly summarize FL settings of each dataset in TableÂ 4. For the cross-silo setting, we used Berka tabular dataset (Berka, 1999), MQP clinical text dataset (McCreery etÂ al., 2020), and ISIC oncological image dataset (Codella etÂ al., 2018) (also a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)). For the cross-device setting, we used CelebA vision dataset (Liu etÂ al., 2015), Reddit text dataset (both are parts of LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019)) and SpeechCommands audio dataset (Warden, 2018).

Instead of manually partitioning data to simulate statistical heterogeneity, we adopt natural client partitions inherent in each dataset. Each client dataset is split into an 80% training set and a 20% test set in a stratified manner where applicable. All experiments are run with 3 different random seeds after tuning hyperparameters. See AppendixÂ C for full descriptions of the experimental setup.

Improvement in the Client-Level Fairness

We compare our methods with existing fair FL methods including FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), AFL (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), q-FedAvg (Li etÂ al., 2019), TERM (Li etÂ al., 2020a), FedMGDA (Hu etÂ al., 2022), and PropFair (Zhang etÂ al., 2022). Since AFL requires full synchronization of clients every round, it is only compared in the cross-silo setting.

In the cross-silo setting, we assume all Kğ¾K clients participate in Tğ‘‡T federation rounds (i.e., C=1ğ¶1C=1), and in the cross-device setting, the client participation rate Câˆˆ(0,1)ğ¶01C\in(0,1) is set to ensure 555 among Kğ¾K clients are participating in each round. We evaluate each dataset using appropriate metrics for tasks as indicated under the dataset name in TableÂ 2 andÂ 3, where the average, the best (10%), the worst (10%), and Gini coefficient222The Gini coefficient is inflated by (Ã—102absentsuperscript102\times 10^{2}) for readability. of clientsâ€™ performance distributions are reported with the standard deviation inside parentheses in gray color below the averaged metric.

From the results, we verify that AAggFF can lead to enhanced worst-case metric and Gini coefficient in both settings while retaining competitive average performance to other baselines. Remarkably, along with the improved worst-case performance, the small Gini coefficient indicates that performances of clients are close to each other, which is directly translated into the improved client-level fairness.

Connection to Accuracy Parity

As discussed inÂ (Li etÂ al., 2019), the client-level fairness can be loosely connected to existing fairness notion, the accuracy parityÂ (Zafar etÂ al., 2017). It is guaranteed if the accuracies in protected groups are equal to each other. While the accuracy parity requires equal performances among specific groups having protected attributesÂ (Zafar etÂ al., 2017; Cotter etÂ al., 2019), this is too restrictive to be directly applied to FL settings, since each client cannot always be exactly corresponded to the concept of â€˜a groupâ€™, and each clientâ€™s local distribution may not be partitioned by protected attributes in the federated system.

With a relaxation of the original concept, we adopt the notion of accuracy parity for measuring the degree of the client-level fairness in the federated system, i.e., we simply regard the group as each client. As a metric, we adopt the accuracy parity gap (Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}) proposed byÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2019; Chi etÂ al., 2021), which is simply defined as an absolute difference between the performance of the best and the worst performing groups (clients). The results are in TableÂ 5 and TableÂ 6. It can be said that the smaller the Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, the more degree of the accuracy parity fairness (and therefore the client-level fairness) is achieved.

It should be noted that strictly achieving the accuracy parity can sometimes require sacrifice in the average performance. This is aligned with the result of Reddit dataset in TableÂ 6, where FedMGDAÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2022) achieved the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG}, while its average performance is only 10.58 in TableÂ 3. This is far lower than our proposed methodâ€™s average performance, 12.95. Except this case, AAggFF consistently shows the smallest Î”â€‹AGÎ”AG\Delta\text{AG} than other baseline methods, which is important in the perspective of striking a good balance between overall utility and the client-level fairness.

Plug-and-Play Boosting

We additionally check if AAggFF can also boost other FL algorithms than FedAvg, such as FedAdam, FedAdagrad, FedYogi (Reddi etÂ al., 2020) and FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020c). Since the sequential decision making procedure required in AAggFF is about finding a good mixing coefficient, ğ’‘ğ’‘\boldsymbol{p}, this is orthogonal to the minimization of ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}. Thus, our method can be easily integrated into existing methods with no special modification, in a plug-and-play manner.

For the verification, we test with two more datasets, Heart (Janosi etÂ al., 1988) and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015), each of which is suited for binary and multi-class classification (i.e., 200 classes in total). Since the Heart dataset is a part of FLamby benchmark (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022), it has pre-defined K=4ğ¾4K=4 clients. For the TinyImageNet dataset, we simulate statistical heterogeneity for K=1,000ğ¾1000K=1,000 clients using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration of 0.010.010.01, following (Hsu etÂ al., 2019). The results are in TableÂ 7, where the upper cell represents the performance of a naive FL algorithm, and the lower cell contains a performance of the FL algorithm with AAggFF. While the average performance remains comparable, the worst performance is consistently boosted in both cross-silo and cross-device settings. This underpins the efficacy and flexibility of AAggFF, which can strengthen the fairness perspective of existing FL algorithms.

7 Limitations and Future Works

Our work suggests interesting future directions for a better FL system, which may also be a limitation of the current work. First, we can exploit side information (e.g., parameters of local updates) to not preserve all clientsâ€™ mixing coefficients, and filter out malicious signals for robustness. For example, the former can be realized by adopting other decision making schemes such as contextual Bayesian optimization (Char etÂ al., 2019), and the latter can be addressed by clustered FL (Ghosh etÂ al., 2020; Sattler etÂ al., 2020) for a group-wise estimation of mixing coefficients. Both directions are promising and may improve the practicality of FL systems. Furthermore, the FTRL objective can be replaced by the Follow-The-Perturbed-Leader (FTPL) (Kalai & Vempala, 2005), of which random perturbation in decision making process can be directly linked to the differential privacy (DP (Dwork, 2006)) guarantee (McMillan, 2018), which is frequently considered for the cross-silo setting. Last but not least, further convergence analysis is required w.r.t. the parameter perspective along with mixing coefficients, e.g., resorting to bi-level optimization framework.

8 Conclusion

For improving the degree of the client-level fairness in FL, we first reveal the connection of existing fair FL methods with the OCO. To emphasize the sequential decision making perspective, we propose improved designs and further specialize them into two practical settings: cross-silo FL & cross-device FL. Our framework not only efficiently enhances a low-performing group of clients compared to existing baselines, but also maintains an acceptable average performance with theoretically guaranteed behaviors. It should also be noted that AAggFF requires no extra communication and no added local computation, which are significant constraints for serving FL-based services. With this scalability, our method can also improve the fairness of the performance distributions of existing FL algorithms without much modification to their original mechanism. By explicitly bringing the sequential decision making scheme to the front, we expect our work to open up new designs to promote the practicality and scalability of FL.

Impact Statement

Federated Learning (FL) poses a potential risk of skewed performance distributions toward partial sub-groups of clients. We believe that our proposed method can mitigate such an unfair situation in the FL system, thereby enhancing the trustworthiness of the FL system and social welfare. A potential concern is the situation where malicious clientd deliberately inflates their local signals to cause global updates to be biased towards themselves. To prevent such a catastrophic situation, we aim to improve the current work by exploiting information other than local losses, as mentioned in the Limitations and future work section. Authors are not aware of other critical ethical/social implications otherwise, but are open to discussing them if exist.

which is later subsumed by q-FedAvg as its special case for the algorithm-specific constant qğ‘q, where qâ†’0â†’ğ‘0q\rightarrow 0.

The objective of q-FedAvg is therefore defined with a nonnegative constant qğ‘q as follows.

minğœ½âˆˆâ„dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1K1q+1â€‹ninâ€‹Fiq+1â€‹(ğœ½)=minğœ½âˆˆâ„dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Kninâ€‹F~iâ€‹(ğœ½),subscriptğœ½superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾1ğ‘1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘1ğœ½subscriptğœ½superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘›subscript~ğ¹ğ‘–ğœ½\begin{gathered}\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{1}{q+1}\frac{n_{i}}{n}F_{i}^{q+1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\\ =\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\tilde{F}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right),\end{gathered} (16)

which is reduced to FedAvg when q=0ğ‘0q=0.

A.2 Technical Lemmas

In this section, we provide technical lemmas and proofs (including deferred ones in the main text) required for proving TheoremÂ 5.1, TheoremÂ 5.2, and CorollaryÂ 5.3.

A.2.1 Strict Convexity of Decision Loss

Lemma A.1.

For all tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], the decision loss â„“(t)superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡\ell^{(t)} defined in (4) satisfies following for Î³âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¾01\gamma\in(0,1), i.e., the decision loss is a strictly convex function of its first argument.

â„“(t)â€‹(Î³â€‹ğ’‘+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹ğ’’)<Î³â€‹â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’’),âˆ€ğ’‘,ğ’’âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1,ğ’‘â‰ ğ’’.formulae-sequencesuperscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ›¾ğ’‘1ğ›¾ğ’’ğ›¾superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’‘1ğ›¾superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’’for-allğ’‘formulae-sequenceğ’’subscriptÎ”ğ¾1ğ’‘ğ’’\begin{gathered}\ell^{(t)}\left(\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q}\right)<\gamma\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+(1-\gamma)\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right),\forall\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{q}\in\Delta_{K-1},\boldsymbol{p}\neq\boldsymbol{q}.\end{gathered} (24)
Proof.

From the left-hand side, we have

â„“(t)â€‹(Î³â€‹ğ’‘+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹ğ’’)=âˆ’logâ¡(1+âŸ¨Î³â€‹ğ’‘+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)=âˆ’logâ¡(1+âŸ¨Î³â€‹ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©+âŸ¨(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)=âˆ’logâ¡(Î³â€‹(1+âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹(1+âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)).superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ›¾ğ’‘1ğ›¾ğ’’1ğ›¾ğ’‘1ğ›¾ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ›¾ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ›¾ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡ğ›¾1ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ›¾1ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡\begin{split}&\ell^{(t)}\left(\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q}\right)\\ =&-\log\left(1+\langle\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle\right)\\ =&-\log\left(1+\langle\gamma\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle+\langle(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle\right)\\ =&-\log\left(\gamma(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)+(1-\gamma)(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right).\end{split} (25)

Since the negative of logarithm is strictly convex, the last term becomes

âˆ’logâ¡(Î³â€‹(1+âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹(1+âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©))<Î³â€‹(âˆ’logâ¡(1+âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©))+(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹(âˆ’logâ¡(1+âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©)),ğ›¾1ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ›¾1ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡ğ›¾1ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ›¾1ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡\begin{gathered}-\log\left(\gamma(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)+(1-\gamma)(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right)<\gamma\left(-\log(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right)+(1-\gamma)\left(-\log(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right),\end{gathered} (26)

which satisfies the definition of the strict convexity, thereby concludes the proof. âˆ

A.2.2 Lipschitz Continuity of Decision Loss (LemmaÂ 4.1)

From the definition of the Lipschitz continuity w.r.t. âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|, we need to check if the decision loss â„“(t)superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡\ell^{(t)} satisfies following inequality for the constant Lâˆsubscriptğ¿L_{\infty}.

|â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)âˆ’â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’’)|â‰¤Lâˆâ€‹â€–ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’’â€–âˆ.superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’‘superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’’subscriptğ¿subscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ’‘ğ’’\begin{gathered}\left|\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)-\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right)\right|\leq L_{\infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q}\right\|_{\infty}.\end{gathered} (27)

|â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)âˆ’â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’’)|â‰¤|âŸ¨âˆ‡â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘),ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’’âŸ©|=|âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©1+âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©|=11+âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©â€‹|âŸ¨ğ’’,ğ’“(t)âŸ©âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’‘,ğ’“(t)âŸ©|superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’‘superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’’âˆ‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡ğ’‘ğ’‘ğ’’ğ’‘ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡1ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡11ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡ğ’’superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡ğ’‘superscriptğ’“ğ‘¡\begin{split}&\left|\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)-\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right)\right|\leq\left|\langle\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right),\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q}\rangle\right|\\ &=\left|-\frac{\langle\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}\right|\\ &=\frac{1}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}\left|\left\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle-\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right|\end{split} (28)

A.2.3 Unbiasedness of Doubly Robust Estimator (LemmaÂ 4.3)

Proof.

where ğ•€â€‹(â‹…)ğ•€â‹…\mathbb{I}(\cdot) is an indicator function.

A.2.6 Regret from a Linearized Loss

Corollary A.3.

From the convexity of a decision loss â„“(t)superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡\ell^{(t)} (LemmaÂ A.1), the regret defined in (5) satisfies

Regret(T)â€‹(ğ©â‹†)=âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“(t)â€‹(ğ©(t))âˆ’âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“(t)â€‹(ğ©â‹†)â‰¤âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“~(t)â€‹(ğ©(t))âˆ’âˆ‘t=1Tâ„“~(t)â€‹(ğ©â‹†),superscriptRegretTsuperscriptğ©â‹†superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptâ„“tsuperscriptğ©tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptâ„“tsuperscriptğ©â‹†superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~â„“tsuperscriptğ©tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~â„“tsuperscriptğ©â‹†\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right),\end{gathered} (47)

where â„“~(t)superscript~â„“ğ‘¡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)} is a linearized loss defined as â„“~(t)â€‹(ğ©)=âŸ¨ğ©,ğ (t)âŸ©superscript~â„“ğ‘¡ğ©ğ©superscriptğ ğ‘¡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\rangle and ğ (t)=âˆ‡â„“(t)â€‹(ğ©(t))superscriptğ ğ‘¡âˆ‡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ©ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right).

Proof.

â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘(t))âˆ’â„“(t)â€‹(ğ’‘â‹†)â‰¤âŸ¨ğ’ˆ(t),ğ’‘(t)âˆ’ğ’‘â‹†âŸ©.superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptâ„“ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘â‹†superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ’‘â‹†\begin{gathered}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)})-\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star})\leq\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right\rangle.\end{gathered} (48)

Summing up both sides for tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T], we proved the statement. âˆ

A.2.8 Upper Bound to the Suboptimality Gap

Lemma A.5.

A.2.10 Exp-concavity

Definition A.8.

A function f:Xâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‹â„f:X\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is Î³ğ›¾\gamma-exp-concave if expâ¡(âˆ’Î³â€‹fâ€‹(ğ’™))ğ›¾ğ‘“ğ’™\exp\left(-\gamma f\left(\boldsymbol{x}\right)\right) is concave for ğ’™âˆˆXğ’™ğ‘‹\boldsymbol{x}\in X.

The decision loss defined in (4) is 111-exp-concave.

Remark A.11.

(Remark 7.27 from (Orabona, 2019)) For a positive definite matrix ğ‘©âˆˆâ„KÃ—Kğ‘©superscriptâ„ğ¾ğ¾\boldsymbol{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K}, â€–ğ’‘â€–ğ‘©subscriptnormğ’‘ğ‘©\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{\boldsymbol{B}} is a norm induced by ğ‘©ğ‘©\boldsymbol{B}, defined as â€–ğ’‘â€–ğ‘©â‰œğ’‘âŠ¤â€‹ğ‘©â€‹ğ’‘â‰œsubscriptnormğ’‘ğ‘©superscriptğ’‘topğ‘©ğ’‘\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{\boldsymbol{B}}\triangleq\sqrt{\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}\boldsymbol{B}\boldsymbol{p}} for ğ’‘âˆˆâ„Kğ’‘superscriptâ„ğ¾\boldsymbol{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}. Note that the dual norm of âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥ğ‘©\|\cdot\|_{\boldsymbol{B}} is âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥ğ‘©âˆ’1\|\cdot\|_{\boldsymbol{B}^{-1}}.

A.3 Regret Bound of AAggFF-S: Proof of TheoremÂ 5.1

Remark A.12.

The regularizer of AAggFF-S (i.e., ONS) is proximal since it has a quadratic form.

Proof.

Since LemmaÂ A.4 holds for arbitrary loss function, let us set L(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)â‰œâˆ‘Ï„=1tâˆ’1â„“~(Ï„)â€‹(ğ’‘)+Î±2â€‹â€–ğ’‘â€–22+Î²2â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1tâˆ’1(âŸ¨ğ’ˆ(Ï„),ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’‘(Ï„)âŸ©)2â‰œsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘¡ğ’‘superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡1superscript~â„“ğœğ’‘ğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptnormğ’‘22ğ›½2superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡1superscriptsuperscriptğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ’‘ğœ2{L}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\triangleq\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}(\boldsymbol{p})+\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2} as in (7) with a slight abuse of notation. Note that we set R(t)â€‹(ğ’‘)=Î±2â€‹â€–ğ’‘â€–22+Î²2â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1tâˆ’1(âŸ¨ğ’ˆ(Ï„),ğ’‘âˆ’ğ’‘(Ï„)âŸ©)2superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡ğ’‘ğ›¼2superscriptsubscriptnormğ’‘22ğ›½2superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡1superscriptsuperscriptğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ’‘ğœ2R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2}, which is often called a proximal regularizer.

From the regret, we have:

Remark A.13.

Even though we can enjoy the same regret upper bound in expectation from CorollaryÂ 5.3, it should be noted that the raw regret (i.e., regret without expectation) from ğ’ˆË˜(t)superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğ‘¡\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)} may inflate the regret upper bound from ğ’ªâ€‹(Lâˆâ€‹Kâ€‹Tâ€‹logâ¡K)ğ’ªsubscriptğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğ¾\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right) to ğ’ªâ€‹(LË˜âˆâ€‹Kâ€‹Tâ€‹logâ¡K)ğ’ªsubscriptË˜ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğ¾\mathcal{O}\left(\breve{L}_{\infty}K\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right), where LË˜âˆsubscriptË˜ğ¿\breve{L}_{\infty} is a Lipschitz constant from LemmaÂ A.2, upper bounding â€–ğ’ˆË˜(t)â€–âˆâ‰¤LË˜âˆsubscriptnormsuperscriptË˜ğ’ˆğ‘¡subscriptË˜ğ¿\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\breve{L}_{\infty}. It is because LË˜âˆsubscriptË˜ğ¿\breve{L}_{\infty} is dominated by 1/Câ‰ˆğ’ªâ€‹(K)1ğ¶ğ’ªğ¾{1}/{C}\approx\mathcal{O}\left(K\right), which can be a huge number when if Cğ¶C is a tiny constant. Although this inflation hinders proper update of AAggFF-D empirically, this can be easily eliminated in AAggFF-D through an appropriate choice of a range (C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}) of the response vector, which ensures practicality of AAggFF-D. See AppendixÂ B.2 for a detail.

A.6 Derivation of Closed-From Update of AAggFF-D

The objective of AAggFF-D in (9) can be written in the following form.

minğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘Ï„=1tâ„“~(Ï„)â€‹(ğ’‘)+Î·(t+1)â€‹âˆ‘i=1Kpiâ€‹logâ¡pi=minğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â¡âŸ¨ğ’‘,âˆ‘Ï„=1tâˆ’1ğ’ˆË˜(Ï„)âŸ©+Î·(t+1)â€‹âˆ‘i=1Kpiâ€‹logâ¡pi=minğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â¡âŸ¨âˆ‘Ï„=1tğ’ˆË˜(Ï„),ğ’‘âŸ©+R(t+1)â€‹(ğ’‘)=maxğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â¡âŸ¨âˆ’âˆ‘Ï„=1tğ’ˆË˜(Ï„),ğ’‘âŸ©âˆ’R(t+1)â€‹(ğ’‘).subscriptğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscript~â„“ğœğ’‘superscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1ğ’‘superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡1superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğœsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1ğ’‘subscriptğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1ğ’‘\begin{split}&\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}(\boldsymbol{p})+\eta^{(t+1)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i}=\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle+\eta^{(t+1)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i}\\ &=\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle+R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p})=\max_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle-R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}).\end{split} (89)

It exactly corresponds to the form of the Fenchel conjugate Râˆ—(t+1)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1R^{(t+1)}_{*}, which is defined as follows.

Râˆ—(t+1)â€‹(ğ’‘)=maxğ’‘âˆˆÎ”Kâˆ’1â¡âŸ¨âˆ’âˆ‘Ï„=1tğ’ˆË˜(Ï„),ğ’‘âŸ©âˆ’R(t+1)â€‹(ğ’‘).subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1ğ’‘subscriptğ’‘subscriptÎ”ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğœğ’‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1ğ’‘\begin{gathered}R^{(t+1)}_{*}(\boldsymbol{p})=\max_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle-R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}).\end{gathered} (90)

Thus, we can enjoy the property of Fenchel conjugate, which is

ğ’‘(t+1)=âˆ‡Râˆ—(t+1)â€‹(âˆ’âˆ‘Ï„=1tğ’ˆË˜(Ï„))superscriptğ’‘ğ‘¡1âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡superscriptË˜ğ’ˆğœ\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\nabla R^{(t+1)}_{*}\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)}\right)\end{gathered} (91)

Since we can derive the log-sum-exp form by solving (90) as follows,

we have the closed-form solution for the new decision update.

pi(t+1)=expâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘Ï„=1tgË˜i(Ï„)/Î·(t+1))âˆ‘j=1Kexpâ¡(âˆ’âˆ‘Ï„=1tgË˜j(Ï„)/Î·(t+1)).subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptË˜ğ‘”ğœğ‘–superscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğœ1ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptË˜ğ‘”ğœğ‘—superscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1\begin{gathered}{p}^{(t+1)}_{i}=\frac{\exp\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{g}^{(\tau)}_{i}/\eta^{(t+1)}\right)}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}\exp\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{g}^{(\tau)}_{j}/\eta^{(t+1)}\right)}.\end{gathered} (93)

See also (Helmbold etÂ al., 1998) and Chapter 6.6 of (Orabona, 2019).

Appendix B Detailed Designs of AAggFF

B.1 Cumulative Distribution Function for Response Transformation

Choice of Distributions

We used the CDF to transform unbounded responses from clients (i.e., local losses of clients) into bounded values. Among diverse options, we used one of the following 6 CDFs in this work. (Note that erfâ¡(x)=2Ï€â€‹âˆ«0xeâˆ’y2â€‹dyerfğ‘¥2ğœ‹superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¦2differential-dğ‘¦\operatorname{erf}(x)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\int_{0}^{x}e^{-y^{2}}\mathrm{d}y is the Gauss error function)

  1. 1.

    Weibull (Weibull, 1951): CDFâ€‹(x)=1âˆ’eâˆ’(x/Î±)Î²CDFğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›½\texttt{CDF}(x)=1-e^{-(x/\alpha)^{\beta}}; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale) and Î²=2ğ›½2\beta=2 (shape).

  2. 2.

    Frechet (FrÃ©chet, 1927): CDFâ€‹(x)=eâˆ’(xÎ±)âˆ’Î²CDFğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›½\texttt{CDF}(x)=e^{-(\frac{x}{\alpha})^{-\beta}}; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale) and Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 (shape).

  3. 3.

    Gumbel (Gumbel, 1935): CDFâ€‹(x)=eâˆ’eâˆ’(xâˆ’Î±)/Î²CDFğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›½\texttt{CDF}(x)=e^{-e^{-(x-\alpha)/\beta}}; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale) and Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 (shape).

  4. 4.

    Exponential: CDFâ€‹(x)=1âˆ’eâˆ’Î±â€‹xCDFğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘¥\texttt{CDF}(x)=1-e^{-\alpha x}; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale).

  5. 5.

    Logistic: CDFâ€‹(x)=11+e(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î±)/Î²)CDFğ‘¥11superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›½\texttt{CDF}(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{(-(x-\alpha)/\beta)}}; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale) and Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 (shape).

  6. 6.

    Normal (GauÃŸ, 1809): CDFâ€‹(x)=12â€‹[1+erfâ¡(xâˆ’Î±Î²â€‹2)]CDFğ‘¥12delimited-[]1erfğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›½2\texttt{CDF}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\left[1+\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{x-\alpha}{\beta\sqrt{2}}\right)\right]; we set Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1 (scale) and Î²=1ğ›½1\beta=1 (shape).

Commonly, the scale parameter of all distributions is set to 1, since in (8) we centered inputs to 1 in expectation. Although we fixed the parameters of each CDF, they can be statistically estimated in practice, such as using maximum spacing estimation (Cheng & Amin, 1983).

For imposing larger mixing coefficients for larger losses, the transformation should (i) preserve the relative difference between responses, as well as (ii) not too sensitive for outliers. While other heuristics (e.g., clipping values, subtracting from arbitrary large constant (Zhang etÂ al., 2022)) for the transformation are also viable options for (i), additional efforts are still required to address (ii).

On the contrary, CDFs can address both conditions with ease. As CDFs are increasing functions, (i) can be easily satisfied. For (ii), it can be intrinsically addressed by the nature of CDF itself. Let us start with a simple example.

Suppose we have K=3ğ¾3K=3 local losses: F1â€‹(ğœ½)=0.01,F2â€‹(ğœ½)=0.10,F3â€‹(ğœ½)=0.02formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹1ğœ½0.01formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹2ğœ½0.10subscriptğ¹3ğœ½0.02F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.01,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.02. Since the average is FÂ¯=0.01+0.10+0.023â‰ˆ0.043Â¯F0.010.100.0230.043\bar{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{0.01+0.10+0.02}{3}\approx 0.043, we have inputs of CDF as follows: F1â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=0.23,F2â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=2.31,F3â€‹(ğœ½)/FÂ¯=0.46formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹1ğœ½Â¯F0.23formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹2ğœ½Â¯F2.31subscriptğ¹3ğœ½Â¯F0.46F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.23,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=2.31,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.46. These centered inputs are finally transformed into bounded values as in TableÂ A1.

While all losses become bounded values in [0,1]01[0,1], the maximum local loss (i.e., F2â€‹(ğœ½)=0.10subscriptğ¹2ğœ½0.10F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10) is transformed into different values by each CDF (see underlined figures in the â€˜Transformed Responsesâ€™ column of TableÂ A1). When using the Weibull CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 1.001.001.00, which means that there may be no value greater than 0.10 (i.e., 0.100.100.10 is the largest one in 100%percent100100\% probability) given current local losses. Meanwhile, when using the Frechet CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 0.650.650.65, which means that there still is a 35% chance that some other local losses are greater than 0.100.100.10 when provided with other losses similar to 0.01 and 0.02. This implies that each CDF treats a maximum value differently. When a transformation is easily inclined to the maximum value, thereby returning 1 (i.e., maximum of CDF), it may yield a degenerate decision, e.g., ğ’‘â‰ˆ[0,1,0]âŠ¤ğ’‘superscript010top\boldsymbol{p}\approx[0,1,0]^{\top}.

Fortunately, most of the listed CDFs are designed for modeling maximum values. For example, the three distributions, Gumbel, Frechet, and Weibull, are grouped as the Extreme Value Distribution (EVD) (Kotz & Nadarajah, 2000). As its name suggests, it models the behavior of extreme events, and it is well known that any density modeling a minimum or a maximum of independent and identically distributed (IID) samples follows the shape of one of these three distributions (by the Extreme Value Theorem (Rusnock & Kerr-Lawson, 2005)). In other words, EVDs can reasonably measure how a certain value is close to a maximum. Thus, they can estimate whether a certain value is relatively large or small. Otherwise, the Exponential distribution is a special case of Weibull distribution, and the logistic distribution is also related to the Gumbel distribution. Last but not least, although it is not a family of EVD, the Normal distribution is also considered due to the central limit theorem, since the local loss is the sum of errors from IID local samples. We expect the CDF transformation can appropriately measure a relative magnitude of local losses, and it should be helpful for decision making.

Effects of Response Transformation

We also illustrated that the response should be bounded (i.e., Lipschitz continuous) in section 4.2.1, to have non-vacuous regret upper bound. To acquire bounded response, we compare the cumulative values of a global objective in (1), i.e., âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ‘i=1Kpi(t)â€‹Fiâ€‹(ğœ½(t))superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¾subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p^{(t)}_{i}F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) for the cross-silo setting, and âˆ‘t=1Tâˆ‘iâˆˆS(t)pi(t)â€‹Fiâ€‹(ğœ½(t))superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{i\in S^{(t)}}p^{(t)}_{i}F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) for the cross-device setting.

In the cross-silo experiment with the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF shows the smallest cumulative values, while in the cross-device experiment with the Reddit dataset, the Weibull CDF yields the smallest value. For the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF yields an average performance (AUROC) of 79.37 with the worst performance of 43.75, but the Weibull CDF shows an average performance of 73.02 with the worst performance of 25.00. The same tendency is also observed in the Reddit dataset. The Normal CDF presents an average performance (Acc. 1) of 14.05 and the worst performance of 4.26, while the Weibull CDF shows an average of 12.62 with the worst of 3.35. From these observations, we can conclude that an appropriate choice of CDF is necessary for better sequential decision making, and suitable transformation helps minimize a global objective of FL. Note also that these behaviors are also directly related to the global convergence of the algorithm w.r.t. ğœ½ğœ½\boldsymbol{\theta}.

B.2 Choice of a Response Range

In regard to determining the range of a response vector, i.e., [C1,C2]subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2[C_{1},C_{2}], we can refer to the Lipschitz continuity in LemmaÂ 4.1 and LemmaÂ A.2. For the cross-silo setting, we can set arbitrary constants so that Lâˆ=ğ’ªâ€‹(1)subscriptğ¿ğ’ª1L_{\infty}=\mathcal{O}(1) according to LemmaÂ 4.1. Thus, for all experiments of AAggFF-S, we set C1=0,C2=1Kformulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶10subscriptğ¶21ğ¾C_{1}=0,C_{2}=\frac{1}{K}.

For the cross-device setting, the Lipschitz constant is changed into LË˜âˆsubscriptË˜ğ¿\breve{L}_{\infty}, since it is influenced by the client sampling probability (Cğ¶C). In detail, Cğ¶C is located in the denominator of the Lipschitz constant, LË˜âˆsubscriptË˜ğ¿\breve{L}_{\infty}, which inflates the resulting gradient value as Cğ¶C is a constant close to 0. (e.g., when 10 among 100,000 clients are participating in each round, 1/C=1041ğ¶superscript104{1}/{C}=10^{4}) This is problematic and even causes an overflow problem empirically in updating a new decision. Thus, we propose a simple remedy â€” setting C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} to be a multiple of Cğ¶C, so that the Cğ¶C in the denominator is to be canceled out, according to LemmaÂ A.2. For instance, when C1=0,C2=Cformulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶10subscriptğ¶2ğ¶C_{1}=0,C_{2}=C, resulting Lipschitz constant simply becomes â€–ğ’ˆË˜(t)â€–âˆâ‰¤LË˜âˆ=C1+0+2â€‹(Câˆ’0)Câ€‹(1+0)=C+2â‰ˆ2subscriptnormsuperscriptË˜ğ’ˆğ‘¡subscriptË˜ğ¿ğ¶102ğ¶0ğ¶10ğ¶22\|\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}\|_{\infty}\leq\breve{L}_{\infty}=\frac{C}{1+0}+\frac{2(C-0)}{C(1+0)}=C+2\approx 2, which is a constant far smaller than Tğ‘‡T and Kğ¾K, typically assumed in the practical cross-device FL setting. Therefore, for all experiments of AAggFF-D, we set C1=0,C2=Cformulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶10subscriptğ¶2ğ¶C_{1}=0,C_{2}=C.

Appendix C Experimental Details

C.1 Datasets

For the main experiments in TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3, we used 3 datasets for the cross-silo setting (Berka (Berka, 1999), MQP (McCreery etÂ al., 2020), and ISIC (Codella etÂ al., 2018; OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022)), and 3 other datasets for the cross-device setting (CelebA, Reddit (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), and SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018)). In this section, we describe details of each dataset about its task, metrics, and client partitioning. The statistics of all federated benchmarks are summarized in TableÂ A2. Note that Avg. and Std. in the table refer to the average and a standard deviation of a sample size of each client in the FL system

First, we present details of the federated benchmark for the cross-silo setting.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Berka is a tabular dataset containing bank transaction records collected from Czech bank (Berka, 1999). Berka accompanies the loan default prediction task (i.e., binary classification) of each bankâ€™s customers. It is fully anonymized and is originally composed of 8 relational tables: accounts, clients, disposition, loans, permanent orders, transactions, demographics, and credit cards. We merged all 8 tables into one dataset by joining the primary keys of each table, and finally have 15 input features. From the demographics table, we obtain information on the region: Prague, Central Bohemia, South Bohemia, West Bohemia, North Bohemia, East Bohemia, South Moravia, and North Moravia. We split each client according to the region and excluded all samples of North Bohemia since it has only one record of loan default, thus we finally have 7 clients (i.e., banks). Finally, we used the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve for the evaluation metric.

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    MQP is a clinical question pair dataset crawled from medical question answering dataset (Ben Abacha & Demner-Fushman, 2019), and labeled by 11 doctors (McCreery etÂ al., 2020). All paired sentences are labeled as either similar or dissimilar, thereby it is suitable for the binary classification task. As a pre-processing, we merge two paired sentences into one sentence by adding special tokens: [SEP], [PAD], and [UNK]. We set the maximum token length to 200, thus merged sentences less than 200 are filled with [PAD] tokens, and otherwise are truncated. Then, merged sentences are tokenized using pre-trained DistilBERT tokenizer (Sanh etÂ al., 2019). We regard each doctor as a separate client and thus have 11 clients. Finally, we used the area under the ROC curve for the evaluation metric.

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    ISIC is a dermoscopic image dataset for a skin cancer classification, collected from 4 hospitals. (Codella etÂ al., 2018; OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022) The task contains 8 distinct melanoma classes, thus designed for the multi-class classification task. Following (OgierÂ du Terrail etÂ al., 2022), as one hospital has three different imaging apparatus, its samples are further divided into 3 clients, thus we finally have 6 clients in total. Finally, we used top-5 accuracy for the evaluation metric.

Next, we illustrate details of the federated benchmark for the cross-device setting.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    CelebA is a vision dataset containing the facial images of celebrities (Liu etÂ al., 2015). It is curated for federated setting in LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), and is targeted for the binary classification task (presence of smile). We follow the processing of (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), thereby each client corresponds to each celebrity, having 9,343 total clients in the FL system. Finally, we used top-1 accuracy for the evaluation metric following (Caldas etÂ al., 2019).

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Reddit is a text dataset containing the comments of community users of Reddit in December 2017, and a part of LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019). Following (Caldas etÂ al., 2019), we build a dictionary of vocabularies of size 10,000 from tokenized sentences and set the maximum sequence length to 10. The main task is tailored for language modeling, i.e., next token prediction, given word embeddings in each sentence of clients. Each client corresponds to one of the community users, thus 817 clients are presented in total. Finally, we used the top-1 accuracy for the evaluation metric following (Caldas etÂ al., 2019).

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    SpeechCommands is designed for a short-length speech recognition task that includes one second 35 short-length words, such as â€œUpâ€, â€œDownâ€, â€œLeftâ€, and â€œRightâ€ (Warden, 2018). It is accordingly a multi-class classification task for 35 different classes. While it is collected from 2,618 speakers, we rule out all samples of speakers having too few samples when splitting the dataset into training and test sets. (e.g., exclude speakers whose total sample counts are less than 3) As a result, we have 2,005 clients, and each client has 16,000-length time-domain waveform samples. Finally, we used top-5 accuracy for the evaluation metric.

C.2 Models

For each dataset, we used task-specific model architectures which are already used in previous works, or widely used in reality, to simulate the practical FL scenario as much as possible. For the experiment of the cross-silo setting, we used the following models.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Logistic Regression is used for the Berka dataset. We used a simple logistic regression model with a bias term, and the output (i.e., logit vector) is transformed into predicted class probabilities by the softmax function.

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    DistilBERT (Sanh etÂ al., 2019) is used for the MQP dataset. We used a pre-trained DistilBERT model, from BookCorpus and English Wikipedia (Sanh etÂ al., 2019). We also used the corresponding DistilBERT tokenizer for the pre-processing of raw clinical sentences. For a fine-tuning of the pre-trained DistilBERT model, we attach a classifier head next to the last layer of the DistilBERTâ€™s encoder, which outputs an embedding of 768768768 dimension. The classifier is in detail processing the embedding as follows: (768768768-ReLU-Dropout-222), where each figure is an output dimension of a fully connected layer with a bias term, ReLU is a rectified linear unit activation layer, and Dropout (Srivastava etÂ al., 2014) is a dropout layer having probability of 0.10.10.1. In the experiment, we trained all layers including pre-trained weights.

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    EfficientNet (Tan & Le, 2019) is used for the ISIC dataset. We also used the pre-trained EfficientNet-B0 model from ImageNet benchmark dataset (Deng etÂ al., 2009). For fine-tuning, we attach a classifier head after the convolution layers of EfficientNet. The classifier is composed of the following components: (AdaptiveAvgPool(7,7777,7)-Dropout-888), where AdaptiveAvgPool(câ€‹dâ€‹oâ€‹t,câ€‹dâ€‹oâ€‹tğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘¡cdot,cdot) is a 2D adaptive average pooling layer outputs a feature map of size 7Ã—7777\times 7 (which are flattened thereafter), Dropout is a dropout layer with a probability of 0.1, and the last linear layer outputs an 8-dimensional vector, which is the total number of classes.

Next, for the cross-device setting, we used the following models.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    ConvNet model used in LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019) is used for the CelebA dataset. It is composed of four convolution layers, of which components are: 2D convolution layer without bias term with 32 filters of size 3Ã—3333\times 3 (stride=1, padding=1), group normalization layer (the number of groups is decreased from 32 by a factor of 2: 32, 16, 8, 4), 2D max pooling layer with 2Ã—2222\times 2 filters, and a ReLU nonlinear activation layer. Plus, a classifier comes after the consecutive convolution layers, which are composed of: (AdaptiveAvgPool(5,5555,5)-111), which are a 2D adaptive average pooling layer that outputs a feature map of size 5Ã—5555\times 5 (which are flattened thereafter), and a linear layer with a bias term outputs a scalar value since it is a binary classification task.

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    StackedLSTM model used in LEAF benchmark (Caldas etÂ al., 2019) is used for the Reddit dataset. It is composed of an embedding layer of which the number of embeddings is 200, and outputs an embedding vector of 256 dimensions. It is processed by consecutive 2 LSTM (Hochreiter & Schmidhuber, 1997) layers with the hidden size of 256, and enters the last linear layer with a bias term, which outputs a logit vector of 10,000 dimensions, which corresponds to the vocabulary size.

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    M5 (Dai etÂ al., 2017) model is used for the SpeechCommands dataset. It is composed of four 1D convolution layers followed by a 1D batch normalization layer, ReLU nonlinear activation, and a 1D max pooling layer with a filter of size 4. All convolution layers EXCEPT the input layer have a filter of size 333, and the numbers of filters are 64, 128, and 256 (all with stride=1 and padding=1). The input convolution layer has 64 filters with a filter of size 808080, and stride of 444. Lastly, one linear layer outputs a logit vector of 35 dimensions.

C.3 Hyperparameters

Before the main experiment, we first tuned the hyperparameter of all baseline fair FL algorithms from a separate random seed. The hyperparameter of each fair algorithm is listed as follows.

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    AFL (Mohri etÂ al., 2019) â€” a step size of a mixing coefficient âˆˆ\in{0.01, 0.1, 1.0}

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    q-FedAvg (Li etÂ al., 2019) â€” a magnitude of fairness, âˆˆ\in{0.1, 1.0, 5.0}

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    TERM (Li etÂ al., 2020a) â€” a tilting constant, Î»ğœ†\lambda, âˆˆ\in{0.1, 1.0, 10.0}

  4. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    FedMGDA (Hu etÂ al., 2022) â€” a deviation from static mixing coefficient âˆˆ\in{0.1, 0.5, 1.0}

  5. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    PropFair (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) â€” a baseline constant âˆˆ\in{2, 3, 5}

Note that client-side optimization in all experiments is done by the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer.

C.4 Implementation Details

All code is implemented in PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al., 2019), simulating a central parameter server that orchestrates a whole FL procedure and operates AAggFF. We further simulate Kğ¾K participating clients having their own local samples, and a communication scheme with the central server. All experiments are conducted on a server with 2 IntelÂ®XeonÂ®Gold 6226R CPUs (@ 2.90GHz) and 2 NVIDIAÂ®TeslaÂ®V100-PCIE-32GB GPUs.

After updating whole entries of a decision variable, the server only exploits mixing coefficients of which indices correspond to selected clients. Denoting as ğ’‘~(t+1)âˆˆÎ”|S(t)|âˆ’1superscript~ğ’‘ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ”superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡1\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}^{(t+1)}\in\Delta_{|S^{(t)}|-1}, each selected entry is normalized as follows.
